THAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name ... Bertha Rowley ...
Address ... Howardon, Sask ...
Birthplace ... St. Louis, Mich ...

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ... 1906 ...
Where did you set up housekeeping? ... On a homestead at Stanley ...
Where had you been living before that? ... Minneapolis ...
For how many people did you prepare meals? ... Twelve ...
How far was it to your nearest store? ... One town northwest of Stanley ...
How often could a visit be made to the store? ... It was twenty miles ...
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ... Generally made flour, tea, coffee, sugar, syrup, salt & spices ...

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ... Royal Household ...
In what quantities did you buy it? ... 150 lbs ...
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ... $2.00 ...
How much did you use graham flour? ... None ...
Whole wheat flour? ... None ...
Was flour milled locally? ... No ...
How far away? ... 65 mi ...
What year? ... 1906 ...
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ... X ...
What other grain products did you use? ... None ...
Cornmeal? ... None ...
Whole wheat? ... None ...
Farina? ... None ...
Other? ... None ...
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ... Same ...
How did you grind it? ... In a feed mill ...
1. THE FAMILY

What year did you start housekeeping? In northern Canada? 1906.

Where did you get your housekeeping? Own home fixed at Stanley.

How far had you been living before that? All my life.

For how many people? Five adults.

How far was it to your nearest store? About three miles.

How often could a visit be made to the store? At least once a month.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, tea, coffee, sugar, syrup, salt, spices.

2. FLOUR AND THEIR GRILL PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household.

In what quantities did you buy? 5 lbs.

That was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $8.00.

How much did you use white flour? Never.

Was flour rolled locally? No.

That was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled flour? $2.40.

Just other grain products did you use? Cornmeal.

Cornmeal when? Morning.

Other? Maternal.

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes.

How did you grind it? By hand.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 14.7.20 lb. bags.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $3.00.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Crown Bread.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? Generally 20 lb.
At what price? About $1. to $5.00.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We bought.
Butter? Made at home.
Eggs? Had them.
What was the price of butter? 20 cents.
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.
Did you make butter? Yes.
What kind of cheese? Can't tell what kind.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? We butchered.
How did you get fresh meat? Bought at the store.
How often did you get fresh meat? In the fall.
How did you preserve meat? Curing with salt.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not at that date.
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Yes.
What kinds? We had wild ducks, quail, and venison.
For how long? We still get these animals.
What part did fish play in the family diet? Mainly.
Kinds? Salmon, smelt, salmon, catfish etc.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Cured.
Kinds? Salmon, smelt, salmon, catfish etc.
3. SEASONS AND STAPLES

In what quantity did you buy whale butter? (10 lbs.)
What was the price? For a can of molasses?
What kind of flour did you usually buy? (Cornmeal)
What size of tin or syrup did you usually buy? (Half-gallon)
At what price? (10 cents)

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? (From neighbors)
Butter? (Milked at home)
That was the price of butter? (25 cents)
Did you keep eggs for "interior" use? (Yes)
Did you make butter? (Yes)
What kind of cheese? (Cheddar)
Can't tell about cheese!

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? (Meat, canned)
How did you get fresh meat? (Purchased at store)
How often did you get fresh meat? (Once a week)
How did you preserve meat? (Canning, smoking, salting)
Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? (Not at that date)
If so, what year was it organized?
Did you use farms? (Yes)
Did you use farms? (Yes)
For how long? (Until 1918)
That part of the fish play in the family diet? (Mainly)
Was the fish fresh, canned, or smoked? (Fresh)
Kind of? (Salmon)

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1907
Potatoes yes. Cabbage yes. Carrots yes. Onions yes.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10#
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk
What weight? 25 lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes + bulk
What was the price of prunes? ..........
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (aples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
Raisins currants and apple peaches
Apricots loganberries - pears.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by Irving? ..........
peas? ...... corn? ...... beans? ...... Saskatoons? .......
other foods? ................................................................

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1910
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ..........
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ..........
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Garden raised
To what extent? Canned fruit
Did you make your own vinegar? No I think some did.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Both.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer sell? Sunlight.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood mostly.

Where did you get your fuel? At Sand hills about.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

The first years we got wood from sandhills since have burned coal. About 1910-1915 burned hard coal. Later were unable to get it have burned soft coal briquets etc.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Brit. made north star.

What year was it purchased? Price?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Mostly enamel.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? Before we came here.
